summary.seg: This manuscript, copied in the late 16th or early 17th century, contains excerpts from the Euchologion, the liturgical book containing the portions of church services recited by the priest, together with prayers and poems. The selections include the Office of the Lesser Purification (the rite for the blessing of water), prayers by the patristic theologians John Chrysostom and Basil of Caesarea, and two alphabetic poems.

The bulk of the manuscript was copied by two different hands, with brief texts later added to what were probably originally blank pages by two other hands. It was owned at one time by a deacon named Nektarios, brother of a priest named Gregorios, who left a note of ownership on a flyleaf.

msItem.title: Alphabetic poem on the birth of Christ
msItem.note: A later hand has added the title Αλφαβιτος διὰ τὴν γενησιν τοῦ Χριστοῦ
msItem.incipit: f. 1r Ἄναρχος Θεὸς καταβαῖβησκεν· καὶ εκ της παρθένου κατῶκισεν
msItem.explicit: f. 2r Ὧ παρθένε σώζε τους πιστοῦς βασιλεῖς ἣν ὅπως σοζώμεν θα και ἡμῆς

msItem.title: Prayers
msItem.explicit: f. 6v καὶ Υἱὼ καὶ τω Αγίω Πνεύματι, νὺν καὶ αεἶ καὶ εἰς τοῦς αἰώνάς τῶ αιώνων ἀμὴν

msItem.title: Euchologion
msItem.note: Excerpt: Office of the Common Supplication (ed Goar, chapter 44)
msItem.rubric: f. 7r Ακολουθία τῆς κοινῆς παρακλήσεως εὐλογήσαντος τοῦ ἰρέως
msItem.incipit: f. 7r Τῇ Θεοτόκῳ ἐκτενῶς νῦν προσδράμωμεν ἁμαρτωλοὶ
msItem.explicit: f. 21r Ελεήμων γὰρ καὶ φιλάνθρωπος Θεὸς ὑπάρχοις καὶ σοὶ τὴν δόξαν ἀναπέμπομεν

msItem.title: Note on food
msItem.incipit: f. 21v Ένθὺμισις πρός πάντας τούς ἀνθρὼπους τι τοὺς κάμνεἴ χρεἴα να τρόγουν
msItem.explicit: f. 21v κανέναν τρόπου καὶ σίρόπην αμηδώπί

msItem.title: Euchologion
msItem.note: Excerpt: Office of the Lesser Purification (ed. Goar, chapter 19)
msItem.incipit: f. 22r Εὐλογήσαντος τοῦ ἱερέως Αρχόμεθα· τὸ Κύριε εἰσάκουσον
msItem.explicit: f. 39r καὶ σῶσον τὰς ψυχὰς ὡς ἀγαθὸς καὶ φιλάνθρωπος:+ καὶ ἀπόλυσιν

msItem.title: List of groups for whom to pray
msItem.incipit: f. 39v Ευξομεθα υπερ τῶν ευσεβών· καὶ ορθοδόξων χριστιανῶν
msItem.explicit: f. 39v και υπερ πᾶντών τών προ αναπαυσα

msItem.author: Basil of Caesarea (c. 329-379)
msItem.title: Orationes sive Exorcismi
msItem.rubric: f. 40r Εὐχαῖ ἥτοι ἐξορκισμοὶ τοῦ μεγάλου Βασιλεῖου προς
msItem.incipit: f. 40r Ὁ Θεὸς τὸν Θεὸν καὶ Κύριος τῶν Κύριον
msItem.explicit: f. 50r καὶ σοὶ τὴν δόξαν ἀναπέμπομεν τῶ Πατρὶ καὶ τω Υἱῶ, καὶ τῶ Ἁγίω Πνεύματι· νὴν καὶ ἀεὶ, καὶ εἰς τοῦς αἰῶνας τῶν αιώνων ἀμὴν

msItem.author: John Chrysostom (d. 407)
msItem.title: Precatio in obsessos
msItem.rubric: f. 50r Εὐχῆ τοῦ Χρυσοστόμου· εἰς τα αυτον τοῦ Χριστοῦ Κυρίου δέηθῶμεν
msItem.incipit: f. 50r Ὁ Θεὸς ὁ αιώνιος, ὁ λιτροσάμενος τὸ γένος τῶν ἀνθρώπων ἐκ τὴν αἰχμαλωσίας τοῦ διαβόλου, ρῦσαι τὸν δοῦλον σου
msItem.explicit: f. 51r σὺν τῶ παναγίω, καὶ αγαθῶ καὶ ζωοποιῶ Πνεύματι· νὴν καὶ αεὶ καὶ εἰς τοῦς αἰῶνας τῶν αἰώνων ἀμὴν

msItem.author: John Chrysostom (d. 407)
msItem.title: Precatio
msItem.rubric: f. 51r Εὐχῆ ετέρα τοῦ αυτοῦ· τοῦ Κυρίου θ
msItem.incipit: f. 51r Ὁ πᾶσιν ακαθάρτοις πνεύμασιν ἐπιτιμήσας, καὶ δυνάμη ρήματος ἐκδιώξας τον λεγεῶνα
msItem.explicit: f. 51v μεθ οῦ εὐλογητὸς εἶ σὺν τω παναγίω, καὶ ἀγαθῶ καὶ ζωοποιῶ σου Πνεύματι· νῦν καὶ εἰς

msItem.author: John Chrysostom (d. 407)
msItem.title: Precatio
msItem.rubric: f. 51v Εὐχῆ ετερα του αὐτοῦ· του Κυρίου δεηθώμεν
msItem.incipit: f. 51v Ἐπικαλοῦμεθά σου δεσποτα Θεὲ παντωκράτορ
msItem.explicit: f. 52r ὅτι σὺ Κύριος μόνος ὕψιστος παντοκράτωρ ευλογητὸς εἰς τοῦς αἰῶνας τῶν αἰώνων ἀμὴν

msItem.author: John Chrysostom (d. 407)
msItem.title: Precatio
msItem.rubric: f. 52r Εὐχῆ ετερα τοῦ αὐτοῦ· τοῦ Κυρίου δεηθώμεν
msItem.incipit: f. 52v Την θεῖαν τε καὶ ἀγίαν και μεγάλην καὶ φρικτὴν καὶ ἄστεκτον ὀνομασίαν
msItem.explicit: f. 58r καὶ τῶ παναγίω καὶ αγαθῶ, καὶ ζωοποιῶ αυτου Πνεύματι νῦν καὶ ἀεὶ καὶ εἰς τοῦς αιωνας τῶν αἰώνων αμὴν

msItem.title: Prayer
msItem.rubric: f. 58v Εὐχῆ λεγομένη ὑπὸ αρχἰερέος· ἢ πνευματίκοῦ πατρὸς· ἐπὶ τοῦς μέλλοντάς· μεταλαβεῖν τῶν αχρὰν των μυστηρίων
msItem.incipit: f. 58v Κύριε Ἰησοῦ Χριστὲ ὁ Θεὸς ἡμῶν Υἱὲ καὶ λόγε τοῦ Θεοὺ τοῦ ζῶντος· πιμὴν καὶ ἀννὲ· ἔρων τὴν αμαρτίαν τοῦ κόσμου
msItem.explicit: f. 62v καὶ τῶ παναγίω καὶ αγαθῶ, καὶ ζωοποιῶ σου Πνεύματι νῦν καὶ ἀεὶ· καὶ εἶς τοῦς αιῶνας τῶν αἰώνων ἀμὴν

msItem.title: Alphabetic poem
msItem.explicit: f. 64r Ὡς αγαθὼς ελέησον ὡς ελεἧμων σώσον

support.material: ff. i recto-6v Western paper, folded in octavo. Watermark: Unidentified motif at the top of the gutter.
ff. 7r-14v, 22r-37v Western paper, folded in octavo. Watermark: Anchor ( c. 53 c. 45 ) at the top of the gutter, similar to Mošin 2245. This example is dated to 1600-1610.

ff. 15-21, 38-65 Western paper, folded in octavo. Watermark:
Anchor ( c. 53 c. 45 ) at the top of the gutter.

supportDesc.foliation: The manuscript is foliated with the numbers [a-c] + i-ii, 1-64 + [d-e], in Arabic and Roman numerals, in pencil, recto, upper right. Beginning with f. 21 (previously numbered 20), the initial foliation has been cancelled by a later hand, also using pencil, and replaced with numbers larger by one, producing the current sequence [a-c] + i-ii, 1-19, 21-65 + [d-e]. The replacement numbers are too large by one for their actual position in the manuscript.

collation.p: The manuscript consists of nine quires, of which one is a binion and the rest are quaternia.

list.item: Quire 38-2 ff. 15-19, 21 The last two folios have been cancelled, without loss of text.

collation.signatures: There are quire signatures in Greek numerals, in black ink, on the first folio of each quire, recto, lower centre or upper centre, and the last folio of each quire, verso, lower centre. Many are absent. They survive on Quires 1-5, with errors. Quire 3 has the number 2 (βʹ) marked at the beginning and no signature at the end, Quire 3 has 4 (δʹ) at the beginning and 5 (εʹ) at the end, and Quire 5 has no signature at the beginning and 7 (ζʹ) at the end.

supportDesc.condition: There is serious pest damage throughout, causing extensive losses to the outermost folios (ff. i-ii, 65). This has been repaired with Japanese paper. There are areas of dirt in the outermost folios.

handNote.p: ff. 1r-21r and 22r-39r were copied by Hand A in an upright mixed minuscule script, in black ink, with little variation in letter size.

Syllabic abbreviations and superscript word endings appear throughout the line. Breathings are round and mute iota is subscript. There is decorative use of the double dot, and accentuation of all nomina sacra. Accents are sometimes joined to abbreviations.
Punctuation used includes the lower and middle points, lower comma and full stop. Most punctuation is marked in red ink, full stops in black and red.
Headings are written in the same style in red ink.
f. 21v was copied by Hand B in an inelegant mixed minuscule script with variable slant, in black ink, with moderate variation in letter size. The loops of some letters have red infill.
Syllabic abbreviations and superscript word endings appear throughout the line. Breathings are round. There is decorative use of the double dot. Some accents and most breathings are omitted.
The only punctuation used is the middle point.
f. 39v was copied by Hand C in an inelegant mixed minuscule script, slanting to the right, in black ink, with little variation in letter size.
Syllabic abbreviations and superscript word endings appear throughout the line. Breathings are absent. Accents are sometimes joined to abbreviations.
The only punctuation used is the middle point.
ff. 40r-64r were copied by Hand D in mixed minuscule script, slanting slightly to the right, in black ink, with moderate variation in letter size.

Syllabic abbreviations and superscript word endings appear throughout the line. Breathings are round and mute iota is absent. There is decorative use of the double dot, and accentuation of all lengths of nomina sacra. Accents and breathings are often omitted or erroneous.
Punctuation used includes the middle and upper points, lower and middle commas and full stop.
Headings are written in the same style in red ink.

decoDesc.decoNote: The beginning of the texts on ff. 7r and 22r are preceded by rectangular plaited headpieces, outlined in black ink with red infill, that on f. 40r by a headpiece outlined in black ink with red and green infill and that on f. 65v by one in black ink only. The text on f. 21v is preceded by a very crude headpiece in red and black ink.
Texts and sections begin with in initials in red ink, with varying size and degrees of ornamentation.

additions.p: There are a number of prayers and other notes on ff. i verso-ii verso and 64v-65r, including an ownership note of the deacon Nektarios on f. i verso, Ετούτη βιφίλο θα ηπαρχη του κυρ διάκου του κυρ Νέκτάριου του πάπα κυρ Γρήγωρίου του αδελφού καὶ ὁπιος τω απόξενόσι να έχη τας άαρας του αγήων πατέρων των τιηʹ θεοφόρων τὼν εν Ηκαία σίνόδου αμήν καὶ ημων τὼν αμάρτωλων τὼν ληποιρὼν επαγώγε χημάζουσὶ τὴν αθλήαν, and a note dated 1641 on f. ii verso, ͵αχμαʹ ἠπεσεν του αγίου Ιωάννου πεμπτην ημέραν
A later hand has added a heading for the text beginning on f. 1r: Αλφαβιτος διὰ τὴν γενησιν του Χριστοῦ.
There are occasional marginal annotations and pen-trials in Greek, including a series of names on f. 1v, Μάρκος Αντόνι Αλεξάνδρο and f. 2r: Ζαβάνια.
The former classmarks D.19 and 236 are written on f. i recto.

binding.p: 18th-century binding with grey paper covering over couched-laminate boards, with a white parchment spine and plain pastedowns. The classmark appears on the spine on patches.
binding.condition: Much of the parchment covering material from the spine has been lost. This damage has been repaired with thick paper.

history.origin: The manuscript was copied in the late 16th or early 17th century, before 1641, as indicated by the watermarks and the presence of a note dated in that year on f. ii verso.
history.provenance: Owned by the deacon Nektarios Nektarios, deacon , as indicated by his note on f. i verso.
history.acquisition: Donated by the antiquary Roger Gale (1672-1744) Gale, Roger, 1672-1744 in 1738.

availability.p: Visitors to Trinity College who wish to consult Special Collections material are required to apply to the Library in advance of their visit. For information on eligibility and admission procedures see: Trinity College: Information for Readers.
